Row.Text: Justinian the First, known as Flavius Petrus Sabbatius Iustinianus in Latin, was emperor of the Byzantine Empire from 527 until his death in 565. His four decades of rule marked the greatest expansion of the Byzantine Empire since its split with the Roman Empire and a sweeping revival in the Christian religion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Born in a small village in modern Macedonia, Justinian had little connection to power in Constantinople as a youth. It was the rise of his uncle, Justin, a Byzantine general who succeeded the Emperor Anastasius, which drew young Justinian from the Macedonian pastures into cosmopolitan Constantinople. Justinian served his uncle as a close advisor for a decade before the passing of Emperor Justin transferred the diadem to Justinian.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]With Justinian's rise to power, two other important faces rose to prominence. Belisarius, a close friend of Justinian, became the leader of Justinian's armies and proved himself as a brilliant tactician. The second face belonged to his beautiful and savvy wife, Theodora, who took on the role that Justinian himself once filled, that of the emperor's closest advisor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]One of Justinian's first actions as Emperor was to order a collection of all Roman law, the Corpus Juris Civilis. But not long after the first issuing of the Corpus, an uprising among two rival chariot racing factions, the Blues and the Greens, engulfed Constantinople in a wave of violence and conflagration. Enterprising powers within the city allied against Justinian, using the chaos to declare a new Emperor, Hypatius, a nephew of Anastasius. Justinian, unsure of the strength of usurpers, decided to flee the city, but his brave wife refused. Instead, Belisarius was ordered to take two divisions and quell the uprising, which he did with ruthless ability, trapping rioters in the Hippodrome and killing nearly 30,000 before the riot was finally put down.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The damage done to the city after the riots was substantial. Among the smoldering ruins lay the Hagia Sophia, Constantinople's greatest cathedral, burnt to the ground. Justinian thus began a monumental campaign to expand and restore the building. With its completion five years later, the reconstructed Hagia Sophia was christened as the world's largest cathedral, a title it would hold for a millennium. Under Justinian`s order, twenty-five cathedrals were built in Constantinople alone, with many more built outside the capital city.

The Empire thrived under Justinian. Thanks in no small part to the able command of Belisarius, Emperor Justinian's reach spread from Constantinople to Southern Spain, with North Africa and Italy all falling under the Byzantine grasp. Justinian's reign marked a high point for the Byzantine Empire, as shortly after his death, much of the land conquered in his name was lost. War with powerful Germanic tribes and neighboring Persia would cost the empire much of its hard-fought gains.

Blessings unto Christ's favoured son, Saint Justinian, Emperor of Byzantium and champion of Rome. Rome had been lost for some two centuries until your ambitious renovatio imperii. Her laws, once the beacon of the civilized world, had too fallen into disuse. But your great feats would herald Rome's closest restoration, and the great Corpus Juris Civilis would form the basis of Europe's laws for centuries to come. Yours is truly a legacy worthy of the Caesars that came before.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Great emperor, the glory of Rome once more awaits your divine government. Can you restore her fractured lands? Can you bring law to the corners of her empire? Can you build a civilization that will stand the test of time?
Barracks, Courthouses, and Temples can be constructed for other cities from the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital. On completion, these buildings yield [ICON_GREAT_GENERAL] Great General Points.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]After completion, you will be able to re-construct this building and transfer it to another city.
[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Upon completion, you will be prompted to choose a city to which to move this building.
To diffuse our beliefs, laws, and tactics, and to ensure that they are followed universally, we must dispatch our greatest minds to the frontiers of our empire.
+15 XP for all Land Units. Earn [ICON_GOLD] Gold when a unit is trained (not purchased) in this city, equal to their starting experience.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Requires 1 [ICON_RES_HORSE] Horse.

Eliminates extra [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness from an occupied Occupied City. Cost increases based on the number of cities in your empire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Constructing this building in the Capital will allow you to choose an occupied city for its jurisdiction to be moved to.

The Hippodrome is the unique Circus replacement for Byzantium under Justinian I. It increases a civilization's Happiness. However, unlike the Circus, the Hippodrome consumes 1 Horse resource and does not require Horses or Ivory nearby. It increases the starting experience for Land Units trained in this city and produces a small amount of Gold each time a unit is newly trained.

The Hippodrome of Constantinople (literally "Horse Path" in Greek) was constructed in 203 AD by the Emperor Sepitmus Severus. The building was a massive venue for chariot races. While the art of charioteering saw great advances in the Hippodrome - the first four-horse races were held here - much of the venue's renown would stem from its involvement in one of the most terrible massacres in Byzantine history. During the Nika Revolts, a brutal uprising between rival racing factions, nearly 30,000 rioters were slain by Byzantine troops within the Hippodrome.

Replace.Text: Fast and powerful Mounted Unit. Weak to Pikemen. Only Byzantium under Justinian I may build it. This Unit has a higher [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength, defends better, and attacks cities more effectively than the Knight that it replaces. It also [ICON_PRODUCTION] trains faster when your cities are under enemy control, although it otherwise takes longer to train.

The Cataphract is a Byzantine unique unit, replacing the Knight. Cataphracts are slower but more powerful than the Knight unit, making them one of the most dangerous cavalry units. They can move after attacking. They are able to gain defensive bonuses, unlike the Knight. Also their penalty for attacking cities is not as severe. Finally, although they take longer to train initially, they receive a 10% bonus in production for every city of yours under enemy control.

Row.Text: Law cannot function in tatters. We must compile all decrees past and present into a single work if we are to govern a civilized and law-abiding empire. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Requirements:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Must have researched Writing. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]May only be enacted once per game. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Costs:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]{1_Num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]3 [ICON_MAGISTRATES] Magistrates. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Rewards:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Grants the [ICON_CULTURE] Legalism and Citizenship policies. For any policies that you already have, receive a free [ICON_CULTURE] Policy instead.

Law cannot function in tatters. We must compile all decrees past and present into a single work if we are to govern a civilized and law-abiding {1_GovtTitleShort}. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Requirements:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Must have a Government. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]May only be enacted once per game. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Costs:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]{2_Num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]3 [ICON_MAGISTRATES] Magistrates. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Rewards:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Chanceries and Magistrate's Courts can be constructed for other cities from the Capital. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Passes the [ICON_JFD_REFORM] Civil (System) Reform without incurring Cooldown.

Law cannot function in tatters. We must compile all decrees past and present into a single work if we are to govern a civilized and law-abiding emprie. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Rewards:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Grants the [ICON_CULTURE] Legalism and Citizenship policies. For any policies that you already have, receive a free [ICON_CULTURE] Policy instead.

Law cannot function in tatters. We must compile all decrees past and present into a single work if we are to govern a civilized and law-abiding {1_GovtTitleShort}. {1_LeaderName} of {2_CivName} has compiled a great law code known as the Corpus Juris Civilis.

The once great empire that long ago spanned the world is within our reach. We need only seal her name upon our laws and the Roman Empire and her pillars of glory shall be reborn in our image. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Requirements:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Must control at least {2_Num} Cities. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]May only be enacted from the beginning of the Renaissance Era. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]May only be enacted once per game. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Costs:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]{1_Num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]2 [ICON_MAGISTRATES] Magistrates. [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Rewards:[ENDCOLOR] [NEWLINE]------------------------- [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Become known as 'Rome.' [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]A [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age begins. [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Barracks, Courthouses, and Temples yield +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.

{1_LeaderName} has declared the restoration of the Roman Empire.
